conversation:
Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul? Little wonder that you serve me so well.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Narrator: *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I'm not going to follow my order. You will live.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you?
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Your blood is my offering, my oblation, my gift.

Nightwarden Minthara: I trust you have found the sanctuary? I hunger for battle.
Player: Bad news - the prisoner escaped.
Nightwarden Minthara: These creatures have failed me again? I will deal with those responsible later.
Nightwarden Minthara: Did he tell you where his friends are hiding before he fled?
Player: He told me everything.
Nightwarden Minthara: Tell me what you know. The Absolute will reward us with such power if we find this place.
Player: Point to the location of the grove on her map.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I don't have the most trustworthy face.
Nightwarden Minthara: They're half-devil refugees... Nobody wants them.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drowning creature will cling to a blade if nothing else is offered. Be that blade.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: Reject these dreams of a bloodbath.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?
Narrator: *Your body yearns to kill this cleric, more than anything else. You know it, deep down, in your writhing intestines.*
Player: I'm [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]. I mean you no harm.
Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Attack her. The Urge aches for it.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: Indeed. I'll take your head and stick it on a pike.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Now, petal, there's... there's no need for such talk.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: I can give you power. Anything you want!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Just let me go. (Ability Score +1)
Karlach: Poisoned deal. Trust me. Don't believe a word she says.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: What'll it be, petal?
Player: Give me power - the more, the better.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel returns to room
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is not in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her out of position, etc.)
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is not in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her out of position, etc.)
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is already in her room.
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
Isobel: You're here for the protection spell, right? Come on - let's get you fit for purpose.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: The Dark Lady's works aren't for me to question.
Isobel: Mustn't question the great shadow mother, must we?
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I've already been to Moonrise, but I have more work to do indeed.
Isobel: I imagine so, if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing off into the night.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Jaheira: Please, be welcome. Have a drink.
Karlach: Oh my gods!
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

Jaheira: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.
Jaheira: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.
Jaheira: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.
Player: Ketheric Thorm, I presume.
Jaheira: The one and only. He was a Sharran, then. We caught him building an army of Dark Justiciars. With the local druids, we made a powerful alliance and put him down.
Jaheira: But he's returned. Not only does General Ketheric Thorm live again, it seems he is no longer mortal. He has become, in fact, invincible.
Jaheira: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.
Jaheira: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.
Jaheira: You are that hope.
Player: What do you have in mind?
Jaheira: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.
Jaheira: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.
Jaheira: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.
Player: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
Isobel: You're here for the protection spell, right? Come on - let's get you fit for purpose.
Player: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Nightwarden Minthara: The goblins tell me that you extracted a confession from our prisoner, True Soul.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, sister? It is good to have your assistance.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: And once I'm inside?
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: It shall be so.

Narrator: *Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her. Dooming the village would bring foul glory. You can almost taste it.*
Narrator: *This is the one Sceleritas sent you to kill. Every scrap of your marrow yearns to end her.*
Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: Could be entertaining.
Isobel: Don't jest. We're all closer to oblivion than you might think. And when we're gone, there'll be no one left to stop Ketheric.
Isobel: I know you won't.
Isobel: Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Your blood is my offering, my oblation, my gift.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will.

Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1)
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Karlach: Please! She's dreaming if she thinks we'd leave Mayrina here.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.

: False
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Not a hope.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's one or the other.

Isobel: Not a step closer, Marcus. I'm warning you.
Fist Marcus: I don't know what your game is, but you can still redeem yourself if you follow my lead.

NodeContext: Anger in his voice.

Fist Marcus: Let's do this. Remember: Ketheric wants her alive.

: False

[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~Minthara steps up on the stone tower outside the gate to the Druid Grove, she assumes her imposing posture, arms at her back, she locks gaze with the player
Zevlor: This is it. Everything turns on this.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: ~The archer nocks another arrow, when the army arrives beneath Minthara and lowers the bow to watch
Zevlor: Get that damn gate closed!
Zevlor: I know that you are all afraid... but I also know that you have been fighting your whole lives.
Zevlor: We have never been handed the easy choices, or the gentle paths. And this is no different.
Zevlor: These creatures would take our lives, our children... our future. And we must resist!
Narrator: *A splinter of ice works its way into your mind.*

NodeContext: amused, referring to the tiefling leaders inspiring speech to the defenders but talking to the player
Nightwarden Minthara: Now slit his throat, and open that gate. The Absolute wants all of them dead.
NodeContext: simple, to the point - killing is a very ordinary thing to her
Player: Of course - as does my god.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Isobel: The True Soul who's going to save us all. I'm Isobel. Pleased to meet you.
Isobel: The True Soul who's going to save us all. Pleased to meet you.
Narrator: *You choke down the obscene thoughts racking your body with a shiver.*
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Narrator: *As you look into the book's amethyst eyes, you can almost hear a voice. You just have to open the book, and it will be yours. Forever.*

Shadowheart: Curious. Why don't you take a closer look... I'll observe from back here.

Isobel: You'd be a bit late to the party if you did. Ketheric Thorm done for. Or didn't you see that angel carving a path straight toward Moonrise Towers?
Player: Forsake your truce. Kill her.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: The True Soul who's going to save us all. Pleased to meet you.
Narrator: *You choke down the obscene thoughts racking your body with a shiver.*
Player: You're coming with me, cleric.

Orin: Look at it, sneaking and snivelling in the shadows.
NodeContext: Sneering, the player failed to free the victim from the altar
Orin: No trust in my promises, but I smell the tyrant's corpse-reek. You are steeped in his rot.
Orin: See how good I was? How patient while you drained the tyrant's juices for me?
Orin: But Sarevok's crimson was not yours to spill. He was mine. You had no right to take him.
Orin: Did it think it could protect? Did it think it could save? Only the blades can offer salvation.
NodeContext: Hushed, as though to companion on altar, but really for player's benefit. Mocking player's intentions. On  the cusp of killing the victim. 'It' is player.
Player: Her fate is of no interest to me.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: What I want is Mayrina - alive and free.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But she's worthless to you!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Let me leave with the girl, and I'll give you power.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Anything is possible. (Ability Score +1)
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Just let me keep the girl and her babe.
Gale: Not only would this be a vile deal, it would be folly to trust a hag's gifts.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: It's your choice, sweetness.
Player: Keep the girl. I'll take the power.

Nightwarden Minthara: I have been expecting you. The goblins tell me that you forced a confession from our prisoner.
Nightwarden Minthara: Without your help, they would have extracted nothing but screams and blood.
Narrator: *Her thoughts mingle with yours, a cold hand caressing your brain.*
Nightwarden Minthara: You are a True Soul, sister? It is good to have your assistance.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is time for the raid to begin. The grove, and those who are hiding there, will fall.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: They'll die thinking I'm their hero.
Nightwarden Minthara: Exquisite. The Absolute chose well when She chose you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.
Narrator: *The masterful painting she depicts of the massacre awakens you hungrily.*
Player: I've done enough. The battle is yours to fight.
Nightwarden Minthara: I do not intend to lead a suicidal charge. The goblins are expendable; I am not.
Nightwarden Minthara: The Absolute brought you here for a reason - to throw open those gates so we can crush our enemies.
Player: If I do this, I expect to be rewarded.

Isobel: On with you. Unless you want to come back to a gaggle of shadow-cursed Harpers.
Player: I won't let that happen.
Isobel: I know you won't.
Isobel: Don't let Jaheira catch you dawdling.
Narrator: *There is something about her... it would be wonderful to kill her. A perfect tragedy.*
Player: My blood... it's telling me to kill you.
Isobel: And yet you hesitate.
Narrator: *She doesn't believe you will do it. You can see, she wants to believe there is mercy in all, even in the worst.*
Isobel: You aren't the first to threaten me. But I know the eyes of a killer when I see them. You mean me no harm. Do you? An experienced cleric can tell such things.
Narrator: *The Urge within does not want to talk. The restless Urge starts to scream.*
Player: Chase away your putrid desires.
Narrator: *As suddenly as it started, you have tamed the Urge. It slumbers again.*
Isobel: There we are. The real you. Your - affliction, is it? - doesn't rule you, does it.
Player: I won't harm you... I don't know what came over me.
Isobel: Why don't we try again, then? Who are you?
Isobel: Hold - who are you, and what are you doing here?

Player: I am going to save these lands. I- I mean you no harm.

Nightwarden Minthara: I trust you have found the sanctuary? I hunger for battle.
Player: Bad news - the prisoner escaped.
Nightwarden Minthara: These creatures have failed me again? I will deal with those responsible later.
Nightwarden Minthara: Did he tell you where his friends are hiding before he fled?
Player: He told me everything.
Nightwarden Minthara: Tell me what you know. The Absolute will reward us with such power if we find this place.
Player: Point to the location of the grove on her map.
Nightwarden Minthara: So close! Their fate is sealed - and you will be instrumental in the slaughter.
Nightwarden Minthara: Go to their refuge and make your way inside. As a friend.
Player: I don't have the most trustworthy face.
Nightwarden Minthara: They're half-devil refugees... Nobody wants them.
Nightwarden Minthara: A drowning creature will cling to a blade if nothing else is offered. Be that blade.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will gather a raiding party and move into position.
Nightwarden Minthara: You will open the gates from the inside when the time is right to strike.
Nightwarden Minthara: We will cleanse the place of infidels and burn it to the ground in the Absolute's name.
Nightwarden Minthara: And then we will be the first among Her favourites.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Wyll: Not as if you can relate to the killing urge, can you? Hmph - I can taste the hypocrisy from here.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
: True
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.

Crusher: ...thrashed 'is arm with my bare hands. Weaker than pixies, humans.
NodeContext: This goblin is in the  telling a story to the other goblins. We join the conversation in the middle.
Brawler Tiny: Oh ho, you got 'im good!
Crusher: And what're you doin' 'ere with that stink on yer face? Think you can do whatever you want?
Crusher: Think you rule the world, huh?
Crusher: And who're you? 'Nother pest? Everyone just barges in here, thinkin' they rule the world. Hah!
Narrator: *The mark glows, but you feel nothing in response. Your illithid power is beyond reach until you rest.*
Player: Lot of assumptions here. I don't think I'm better than anyone else.
Crusher: Everyone says that. And then they spit in our faces.
Crusher: But no more. Things're changin'. We got the Absolute on our side now.
NodeContext: He's proud of this and wants to rub into our faces that he's better than us because of it.
Crusher: Ya better learn yer place.
Crusher: Go on: kiss my foot.
NodeContext: bullying the player, he feels like they won't dare to refuse.
Crusher: Or I'll wipe that nasty look right off yer face.
Lae'zel: End him or leave him. But don't you dare grovel to this slug.
Player: I'd sooner spit in your face.
Crusher: What was that?
Player: Apologise and drop to your knees.
Crusher: Thought so.
NodeContext: We muttered an insult, but after challenging us, we did what he wanted.
Crusher: That's more like it.
NodeContext: condescending - he asked us to kiss his feet and we got on our knees.
Player: Kiss his foot and get it over with.

Ide: If this is about Rolan, go away.
NodeContext: Upset frustrated
Player: Ignore Rolan. He's just a grump.
Ide: He called me a 'ragged little devil'.
NodeContext: Frustrated and upset. Hurt but tryiing not to show it. Could be mistaken for a bit bratty.
Player: True. But I don't think he meant it.
Ide: Then he should say sorry - all I did was tell him he shouldn't drink anymore.
Ide: It was for his own good! He can barely stand up straight.
Player: I get it - you were trying to look after him.
Ide: Yeah. He did save us, after all.
Ide: Anyway, it's his loss.
Player: What do you mean, his loss?
Ide: I found this book. Old, dusty, full of strange lettering. Pretty sure it's magic.
Ide: I was gonna give it to Rolan so he could learn new spells, you know? Beats drinking 'til he forgets the ones he knows.
Player: Can I have it?
Ide: It's for Rolan.
Player: Give it to me, you brat. Now.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: It's best to not ask where I conduct my... business. For your own safety.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is that so? Enigmatic soul, aren't you?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I didn't come looking for handouts. I take care of myself.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: That might be the simplest approach. Unfortunately, not everyone sees things that way.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: You're supposed to keep the peace, not stoke the fire.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: What peace? If no one steps in, there'll be bodies piled high in the streets before long.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Both sides need teaching a lesson: let's kill them all.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Player lifts lantern and illuminates their face.
Harper Branthos: Incredible. A light so radiant, not even the curse can dim it.
Narrator: *The lantern flickers ever so briefly, and you hear a slight twitter - or perhaps it's simply your imagination.*
Harper Branthos: You. Don't move a godsdamned muscle.
Harper Branthos: Talk. Why in the hells would a cultist turn on their kind?
: False
Narrator: *The pin the man wears is familiar to you. He belongs to the Harpers, a covert organisation dedicated to freedom and balance.*
Player: I'm not one of them. They took me prisoner.
Harper Branthos: A prisoner? Then I must be a welcome sight indeed.
Harper Branthos: Follow me. I know a refuge from the darkness. You can rest there.
Player: How about I just kill you and keep the lantern for myself?
Harper Branthos: Rotten swine!

Gerringothe Thorm: WHAT DO YOU BRING?
NodeContext: a desperate, cacophonous howl
Player: Peace and comfort, I hope.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.
Player: Leave.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU CANNOT LEAVE. YOU MUST PAY.
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE GOLD.
NodeContext: Roared with a shudder of pleasure on 'GOLD'.
Player: Toss the creature a gold piece.
[description] NodeContext: The player tosses a gold piece to the creature. Gerringothe absorbs the gold
Gerringothe Thorm: I REQUIRE MORE!
Player: I don't hand out so much gold for so little in return.
Gerringothe Thorm: YOU MAY PASS THE RIVER. BUT FIRST YOU MUST PAY.
Player: I've already paid.
Gerringothe Thorm: YES! AGAIN!
Player: Fine. Take it all.

Karlach: Pot, meet kettle.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: Don't blame others for what you did.
Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.

Player: I'm glad you made it too, it's one hell of a curse.
Alfira: It wasn't the curse that did us in.
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Someone told them to rot in the Nine Hells, that we weren't going anywhere.
Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: How did you survive?
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: What did the cultists do to the others?
Alfira: I don't know. It just... happened so quickly.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Just take it one step at a time.
Alfira: You make it sound so easy - but I'll try.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

Counsellor Florrick: Wyll? What has become of you?
InternalNodeContext: Player inside the cell
Player: I don't understand. What do you mean?
Counsellor Florrick: I came seeking allies to our cause. Watchers spotted me, dragged me to Ulder Ravengard's husk.
Counsellor Florrick: Empty as a stare. Your father's a tadpole's puppet, Wyll. Nothing more.
Counsellor Florrick: Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more.
Counsellor Florrick: He spoke in accusations. Apostasy, conspiracy, sedition.
Counsellor Florrick: I will soon be hanged on the city gallows to a chorus of cheers.
Counsellor Florrick: You might have unlocked my cell, but there's no escape from this place.
Wyll: The Hells with that. Nothing is over. Not while I still draw breath.
Player: Ravengard's dead. The city needs you - I'm getting you out.
: True
Counsellor Florrick: He's - dead? I prepared myself for this. Thought I was ready. But the sting still pierces deep.
Counsellor Florrick: He - he once told me, 'When the people call for a miracle, you cannot wait for the gods to answer.'
Counsellor Florrick: He was right. No more waiting, no more sulking. I know what to do.
Counsellor Florrick: No more sulking. I know what to do.
Counsellor Florrick: Unlock my cell, escort me out of Wyrm's Rock.
Counsellor Florrick: I'll seek out my connections. When the city's streets shatter, you'll want their blades.
Player: I won't help you.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Enough, Wulbren! Gortash enslaved us, forced us to build his Steel Watchers - but no more.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home and mourn my daughter in peace.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What do you think, Wulbren?
Wulbren Bongle: I think that if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill the Gondians, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Wulbren makes a good point - you must die for the city, Gondians.

Narrator: *The gnomes speak in soft whispers, the words all but lost in the hot air.*
Player: Clear your throat.
Apprentice Laridda: Lunkbug, hush. We're being watched.
Lunkbug: We're working as we can. Very hard indeed.
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: I have news: half the trapped gnomes are already dead.
Lunkbug: Great gods. How - how could you know that?

Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.

Mayrina: That lying, thieving, shitty little redcap. I can't believe I fell for a hag's tricks. Again.

Mayrina: It's not your fault - it's mine. There's a hag hunting me - and for good reason.
Mayrina: This group is made of survivors - people like me who've been hurt by hags. I brought them together to fight back.
Mayrina: We tracked a hag to the city, but lost her trail - right after she snatched a little girl.
Player: Any connection to our old friend Ethel?
Mayrina: I bloody hope not - I see her enough in my dreams. No, Ethel is dead - thanks to you.
Mayrina: But this one is no less of a nightmare.
Mayrina: The moment I started investigating the missing girl, I felt the hag's eye on me. Next thing, I was sprouting wool and bleating up a storm.
Player: Let me guess - you want me to help.
Mayrina: You've seen what Ethel did - imagine the destruction a hag could cause in a city this size? With people this desperate?
Mayrina: Look, I know you're busy with big-time heroics, but we need your help. A child's life is on the line - and her mother is the best lead we've got.
Player: You'll have to deal with this yourself.

Sceleritas Fel: Master. You are the chosen one.

NodeContext: Butler's body beginning to vibrate, and jerk strangely
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The butler levitates, held up in the air like a broken marionette on invisible strings. Daggers manifest in the air around him and plunge into his body, making a gory pincusion of him. His mutilated corpse crashes to the ground, and the blood that runs from it forms a dark pool.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. It is the butler, his hat gone, the flesh peeled back from his skull in places. Thoroughly mutilated and disfigured. His eyes burn with unholy fire - he has become an Avatar of Bhaal.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. Bhaal Avatar: I expected the other.

Narrator: *A gift from your god, your Father. An offering of his affection for you, or confirmation that he owns you.*
Narrator: *Accept Father's gift and you will reap horrors upon this world. But you will be his puppet. This is your final chance to cut your strings...*
GROUP_ORI_DU: What gift does the Lord of Murder propose?
Bhaal Avatar: My Slayer. You will grow stronger. Crueller. The prime incarnation of murder.
GROUP_ORI_DU: What would you have me do with this gift?
Bhaal Avatar: Domination. Slaughter. Mountains of corpses, you standing atop them.
Bhaal Avatar: You must destroy this world. It is what you were made for.
Narrator: *For a moment, the brine-pool of your brain clears. To die: to rest, to save the world from yourself. To accept: to become his prophet - in any disobedience, subject to his lash.*

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.

Dolly Dolly Dolly: I'LL GUT YOU LIKE A TEN-DAY-OLD IF YOU DON'T RELEASE ME RIGHT! THIS! MOMENT!
Player: My, you've changed your tune.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: If you prefer the kinder type, I'll sweetly slurp your guts like tripe!
Player: Ignore the pixie; keep the lantern.

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared
Player: Cultists? What happened?
Alfira: Stars, you hadn't heard?

Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: I've seen a lot of nasty ambushes in my time - but that sounds among the worst. I'm sorry.
Alfira: It just... it just never stops.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: I know - Rolan isn't happy with me.
Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: Danger is my life - there is no greater thrill for me than the hunt.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I imagine the cultists are torturing them right now.

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: It's all right, I'm not here to judge you.
Madeline: You're - you're not? But he said I deserved it. That I'm... evil.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Stab yourself. Rip your stomach open. Feel the pain of your friends - only then will you be free.
Player: Anything? Then hurt yourself as Ben and Marc did - stab yourself.
: True
Madeline: Like... this?
NodeContext: Madeline draws a blade from behind her and holds it in front of her stomach, blade pointed towards her stomach. She is utterly terrified (pose like seppuku)
Player: Start stabbing, and don't stop until I say so.

Lord Enver Gortash: You have the Netherstones - they resonate with my own.
Lord Enver Gortash: I commend you for putting an end to Orin's madness - she must be screaming bloody murder in the Hells even now.
Lord Enver Gortash: How was the reunion? I trust you demonstrated your particular spark of creative genius?
Lord Enver Gortash: I always preferred your methods to hers. You have mastery over your Urges, Orin was consumed by her gruesome obsessions.
Player: My Urges are gone from me, as is any trace of Bhaal.
Lord Enver Gortash: I'm surprised Bhaal allowed you to slip away from his grasp. But this changes nothing.
Lord Enver Gortash: With me, you will have power greater than Bhaal could have given you, and you will bow to no master.
Lord Enver Gortash: My involvement with Orin was never a true alliance. A mad dog understands the yank of the leash and the hand of its master, but it cannot be an equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: You can be my equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: We will raise a Black Keep in Baldur's Gate. Then we will conquer the Sword Coast, and unite all its peoples under our rule. But first -
[description] CinematicNodeContext: The room shakes from a "brainquake".
Lord Enver Gortash: The brain awakens - we must act now. Faithful, come forward.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Several Banites step from the corner shadows, one at a time. They look fierce and dangerous.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Finally, the Steel Watcher stepw forward. It activates, looking devastatingly powerful.
Lord Enver Gortash: Hand me the Netherstones, and we will rule as one.
Gale: Hmm. I can think of more trustworthy accomplices - more than a few, in fact.
Player: If we are to rule together, the stones should be split between us. I keep mine, you keep yours.
Lord Enver Gortash: I'm not here for games. Hand me the stones, or face the black hand of Lord Bane.
Player: We can be allies but Ketheric and Orin's stones stay with me.

Apprentice Laridda: Quiet, Lunkbug. The walls have ears.
Apprentice Laridda: Forget the smokepowder - they'd kill Phil on the spot. I won't let you do it.
NodeContext: Whispered
Player: You can trust me - I'm friendly.
: True
Lunkbug: Laridda. We're hardly overburdened with friends down here. Let's hear them out.
NodeContext: Gently urging his companion to trust us.
Lunkbug: Hear me out - our friends are trapped in the cave-in. And I know a way to get them out.
Apprentice Laridda: Bug, please. True Soul Nere will - you know what he'll do.
Player: That sounds like quite the drama. I can't wait to watch.
Apprentice Laridda: What? No. Lunkbug, you can't.
NodeContext: Pleading with Lunkbug not to say anything.
Lunkbug: I've... I've got no choice, Laridda. We have to chance it.
Lunkbug: A few days back, there was a... a scene. Our friend Philomeen, she's a sapper. Set off a blast and ran off.
Lunkbug: We set a spot for hiding if someone found trouble. I'll mark your map.
Lunkbug: If Philomeen made it, you'll find her there. She'll have the stuff to blow that tunnel wide open and get Beldron and the rest out.
Astarion: High-powered explosives do sound fun, but must we waste them saving lives?
Player: Excellent. I can add Philomeen's head to my collection.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.
Gondian Menalda: Wait - wait! The Banites forced us to make the Steel Watchers, but it's over now. We are his slaves no more.
Gondian Menalda: If you let us go, you will never hear from us again - I swear it.
Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.
Player: What about Gortash? What if he forces you to build up his Steel Watch once more?
Gondian Menalda: We have safe-houses all over the city - he will never find us, I swear it on my life.
("safe houses" as in "safehouses" for shelter)
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.
NodeContext: the mask has truly gone, we see wulbren for what he is - cruel, spiteful and viscious
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren - enough! I won't watch as you poison your soul - and the brilliant future that remains to the Ironhand Gnomes.
Barcus Wroot: I thought the Ironhand Gnomes had corrupted you, Wulbren. Now I wonder if it wasn't the other way around.
Barcus Wroot: Kill Toobin, and you kill all we love: Collaboration. Challenge. Solving problems with the power of reason, creativity, and invention.
Barcus Wroot: I still want to believe you're better than that, Wulbren. But even I am having my doubts.
Player: Wulbren makes a good point - you must die for the city, Gondians.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.

Liam: It's called th-the Nightsong. We tried to s-sneak past the goblins...

Liam: It should be here somewhere. He said there was a hidden passage underneath the temple.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The butler levitates, held up in the air like a broken marionette on invisible strings. Daggers manifest in the air around him and plunge into his body, making a gory pincusion of him. His mutilated corpse crashes to the ground, and the blood that runs from it forms a dark pool.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. It is the butler, his hat gone, the flesh peeled back from his skull in places. Thoroughly mutilated and disfigured. His eyes burn with unholy fire - he has become an Avatar of Bhaal.

Bhaal Avatar: Domination. Slaughter. Mountains of corpses, you standing atop them.
Bhaal Avatar: You must destroy this world. It is what you were made for.

Bhaal Avatar: Your life is mine. Accept your inheritance, or I will reclaim it.

'Yehehueh!' = Fezzerk's distinct laugh (a raspy, mean-spirited slur of a laugh)
